verses.text: When King Hezekiah heard this, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Hezekiah's response is immediate humility and repentance. Sackcloth is a sign of mourning throughout Scripture (see Neh. 9:1), while entering the 'house of the LORD' foreshadows seeking God's presence in crisis.

verses.text: He sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the secretary, and the elders of the priests, all dressed in sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.
verses.comment: The nation's spiritual leaders are sent together, showing respect for prophetic authority and the communal nature of biblical leadership. The mention of a prophet highlights continuity of authority from Moses onward.

verses.text: They told him, 'This is what Hezekiah says: Today is a day of distress, rebuke, and disgrace—as children come to birth, but there is no strength to deliver them.'
verses.comment: The metaphor of spiritual birth points forward to new beginnings; lack of strength hints at human inability. This sets up God's intervention and echoes biblical reliance on divine grace.

verses.text: It may be that the LORD your God will hear all the words of the field commander, whom his master, the king of Assyria, has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words the LORD your God has heard. Therefore, lift up your prayer for the remnant that remains.
verses.comment: Hezekiah appeals to intercessory prayer, recognizing the power of the prophet's prayer for the community. This establishes precedent for mediation and intercession by spiritual leaders.

verses.text: So the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah.
verses.comment: Direct approach to the prophet underlines the trust given to God's spokesman—showing the importance of acknowledging God-ordained authority.

verses.text: Isaiah said to them, 'Tell your master: This is what the LORD says: Do not be afraid of the words you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me.'
verses.comment: God reassures through His prophet—reminding believers not to fear insults or threats against the faith. Trust in God's sovereignty is a recurring biblical principle.

verses.text: 'Look, I will put a spirit in him so that he hears a rumor and returns to his own land, and I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own country.'
verses.comment: God's action involves both spiritual and providential intervention. The mention of spirit recalls God's sovereignty over hearts and nations.

verses.text: Then the field commander returned, and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, for he had heard that he left Lachish.
verses.comment: The narrative continues to trace historical movements, corroborated by archaeological discoveries.

verses.text: Now Sennacherib heard a report concerning Tirhakah king of Cush: 'He has come out to fight against you.' So Sennacherib sent messengers again to Hezekiah, saying,
verses.comment: Assyria's shifting alliances and threats show the constant political turmoil threatening Judah.

verses.text: 'This is what you are to say to Hezekiah king of Judah: Do not let your God, in whom you trust, deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be handed over to the king of Assyria.'
verses.comment: Assyria's arrogance directly challenges faith in God's promises, posing the classic biblical theme of pride versus trust.

verses.text: You have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the other countries, destroying them completely. Will you be delivered?
verses.comment: The enemy assumes no exception for God's people—a theological mistake throughout biblical history.

verses.text: Did the gods of the nations that my ancestors destroyed—Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden in Telassar—deliver them?
verses.comment: Reference to false gods reinforces biblical monotheism. In spiritual terms, it distinguishes the living God from idols.

verses.text: Where are the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?
verses.comment: The Assyrian strategy is intimidation. The text's focus on dead kings contrasts with God’s enduring kingship.

verses.text: Hezekiah received the letter from the messengers, read it, and went up to the house of the LORD and spread it before the LORD.
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s act is both literal and symbolic—laying out the enemy’s threat before God, emphasizing trust in divine intervention.

verses.text: And Hezekiah prayed before the LORD and said: 'O LORD, God of Israel, enthroned above the cherubim, you alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth; you made heaven and earth.'
verses.comment: Emphasizes God's sovereignty and creative power. The reference to cherubim suggests the visible sign of God’s presence, paralleling temple worship and the importance of a physical place of God's dwelling.

verses.text: 'Incline your ear, LORD, and hear; open your eyes, LORD, and see; hear the words Sennacherib has sent to mock the living God.'
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s prayer echoes the psalms—calling on God to vindicate His name. The phrase 'living God' counters idolatry.

verses.text: 'Truly, LORD, the kings of Assyria have laid waste the nations and their lands,'
verses.comment: Acknowledging the reality of destruction sets up a contrast: only God's intervention preserves.

verses.text: 'And have cast their gods into the fire, for they were not gods but only the work of human hands—wood and stone—so they destroyed them.'
verses.comment: A clear declaration of the futility of idols, echoing themes in Genesis and Deuteronomy about the uniqueness of Israel’s God.

verses.text: 'But now, LORD our God, save us, please, from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone, LORD, are God.'
verses.comment: The plea is for God’s glory (not merely national security). This universal scope prefigures the mission to all nations, a repeated New Testament theme.

verses.text: Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent a message to Hezekiah, saying, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I have heard your prayer about Sennacherib king of Assyria.'
verses.comment: The power of prayer is affirmed by direct prophetic response, showing God hears the faithful.

verses.text: 'This is the word the LORD has spoken about him: The virgin daughter of Zion despises you and mocks you; the daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head behind your back.'
verses.comment: Personification of Jerusalem as 'virgin daughter' links to themes of purity and the city as a sacred people, ultimately anticipating a New Covenant bride.

verses.text: 'Whom have you mocked and insulted? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted your eyes in pride? Against the Holy One of Israel!'
verses.comment: 'Holy One of Israel' is a special title emphasizing God's unique holiness—central to Scripture and echoed in the angelic cry of ‘Holy, Holy, Holy’ in Isaiah 6.

verses.text: 'Through your messengers you have insulted the Lord. You have said: "With my many chariots I have ascended the heights of the mountains, the farthest reaches of Lebanon. I cut down its tallest cedars and its choicest cypresses. I entered its farthest retreat, its densest forest."'
verses.comment: Assyrian pride is self-exaltation. The language about chariots and cedars recalls other ancient texts. God opposes the prideful.

verses.text: 'I dug wells and drank foreign waters, and with the soles of my feet I dried up all the streams of Egypt.'
verses.comment: These boastful claims echo the fruitless pride of man—themes deepened in New Testament teaching about humility.

verses.text: 'Have you not heard? Long ago I ordained it, from ancient times I planned it; now I have brought it to pass, that you should turn fortified cities into piles of ruins.'
verses.comment: God's providence and foreknowledge are central; nothing occurs outside His plan. This anticipates the doctrine of God’s sovereignty found throughout salvation history.

verses.text: 'Their inhabitants, shorn of strength, are dismayed and ashamed. They are like plants of the field, like tender green shoots, like grass growing on the roof—scorched before it can grow.'
verses.comment: Human frailty is highlighted, a motif repeated in both Old and New Testaments (see 1 Pet. 1:24).

verses.text: 'But I know where you stay, and where you come and go, and how you rage against me.'
verses.comment: Divine omniscience is stressed—God knows all actions and intentions.

verses.text: 'Because you rage against me and your arrogance has reached my ears, I will put my hook in your nose and my bridle in your mouth, and I will turn you back by the way you came.'
verses.comment: Strong language of restraint depicts God as the true ruler even of rulers. The metaphor is vivid and humiliating for an ancient Near Eastern king.

verses.text: 'This will be a sign for you, Hezekiah: This year you will eat what grows by itself, and in the second year what springs from that. But in the third year, sow and reap, plant vineyards, and eat their fruit.'
verses.comment: The sign is both literal (agricultural recovery) and a symbol of restoration after judgment, prefiguring God's care for His covenant people.

verses.text: 'The surviving remnant of Judah will again take root downward and bear fruit upward.'
verses.comment: Remnant theology is established: God always preserves a faithful remnant. Fruitfulness relates to both material and spiritual flourishing.

verses.text: 'For out of Jerusalem will come a remnant, and out of Mount Zion, survivors. The zeal of the LORD will accomplish this.'
verses.comment: Divine initiative (zeal of the LORD) brings about salvation and restoration despite human weakness.

verses.text: 'Therefore this is what the LORD says about the king of Assyria: He will not enter this city or shoot an arrow here. He will not come before it with shield, or build a siege ramp against it.'
verses.comment: Divine protection is absolute. God’s promises are sure, as seen with Daniel in the lion’s den and the three young men in the fiery furnace.

verses.text: 'By the way that he came he will return; he will not enter this city, says the LORD.'
verses.comment: God’s word will stand against all opposition. This is a perpetual promise for the community of faith.

verses.text: 'For I will defend this city and save it, for my sake and for the sake of David my servant.'
verses.comment: God’s covenant with David is central—a foreshadow of messianic fulfillment. Protection flows from God's faithfulness and promise, teaching continuity between old and new covenants.

verses.text: That night the angel of the LORD went out and struck down 185,000 men in the Assyrian camp. When the people got up the next morning, there were only dead bodies.
verses.comment: Divine intervention by angels underscores spiritual realities behind physical events. The theme of angels as God's agents of deliverance runs throughout Scripture.

verses.text: So Sennacherib king of Assyria broke camp and withdrew. He returned to Nineveh and stayed there.
verses.comment: After supernatural defeat, the enemy departs. Historical records outside the Bible confirm Sennacherib’s return, showing biblical events align with history.

verses.text: While he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with the sword, and they escaped into the land of Ararat. Then his son Esarhaddon succeeded him as king.
verses.comment: The humiliation and death of Sennacherib, even while at worship, highlights the impotence of false deities. Kingship in human hands is transient; true authority belongs to the Lord. This narrative foreshadows the supremacy of God’s kingdom, both earthly and eternal.
